body: While open data in the Caribbean is still in its early stages of adoption, momentum has been steadily building among key stakeholders in the region. Below are some examples of how open data is helping agriculture in the Caribbean.
title: Case studies from the Caribbean

_items.title: HarvestAPI
_items.body:
Where: Jamaica.

Who: SlashRoots Foundation and the Rural Agricultural Development Authority.

What: HarvestAPI is an open source platform that publishes agricultural data across government agencies and with the public. The platform is being developed to increase access to the Government of Jamaica Farmer register. 

Why: Opening up data catalyses innovation in the sector and, in the process, helps overcome some of the structural challenges that limit the access, use and maintenance of quality agricultural data.

Take me to the HarvestAPI website

_items.title: Jamaica Agricultural Marketing Information System (JAMIS)
_items.body:
Where: Jamaica.

Who: The Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, Information Division & RADA.

What: A service that provides unbiased data on farm gates, markets, and wholesale and retail prices on a weekly basis.

Why: To provide accurate and unbiased marketing information depicting current trade conditions. The aim is to promote orderly marketing and enhance competition. 

Take me to the JAMIS website

_items.title: AgriNeTT
_items.body:
Where: Trinidad and Tobago.

Who: The University of the West Indies in collaboration with industry experts.

What: An open data repository, containing datasets from institutions and associations. Datasets included are farm-level production data; commodity prices and volumes; farm land spatial data; soils data; weather data; and pest and diseases tracking data.

Why: For local developers to visualise the data and build applications that are useful to the community. 

Take me to the AgriNeTT website

_items.title: CIRP-mFisheries
_items.body:
Where: Trinidad and Tobago.

Who: The Caribbean ICT Research Programme.

What: A suite of mobile applications designed to improve market conditions, efficiency and safety for small-scale fisherfolk in Trinidad and Tobago.

Why: The government has prioritised development in the fishing industry on account of its economic and social significance. It aims to make this sector competitive, sustainable and profitable, as well as inclusive, equitable and supportive of the local fishing communities. 

Take me to the mFisheries website

_items.title: National Agricultural Market Information System (NAMIS)
_items.body:
Where: Trinidad and Tobago.

Who: The National Agricultural Marketing and Development Corporation.

What: NAMIS publishes buyer and exporter information, as well as price, volume and production data.

Why: To stimulate investments in the agri-food sector by providing data for making strategic, investment, management and policy decisions by all stakeholders.

Take me to the NAMIS website

body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness:
title: What makes data open?

_items.title: Limitations
_items.body:
For data to be open, it should have no limitations that prevent it from being used in any particular way.

Anyone should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data, even commercially.

_items.title: Cost
_items.body:
Open data must be free to use, but this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is often a cost to creating, maintaining and publishing usable data.

Ideally, any fee for accessing open data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested.

This reproduction cost tends to be negligible for many datasets.

Live data and big data can incur ongoing costs related to reliable service provision.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use, reuse and redistribute it – even commercially.

Open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, and should all be carefully considered.

However, these do not make the data more open.

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.
title: What is open data?

displayTitle: Are you ready to apply open data to Caribbean agriculture?
title: Are you ready to apply open data to Caribbean agriculture?

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Governments, businesses and individuals can use open data to help bring about social, economic and environmental benefits.

In this module, we will explore the following:

✓ What is data and what is open data?

✓ What makes data open?

✓ What are the benefits of open data for agriculture?

✓ Case studies of open data and agriculture in the Caribbean
title: Open Data and Agriculture

body: Data is...
title: What is data?

_items.text: information posted on the Web
the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived
numbers, words, maps and photos

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

body: Open data is...
title: What is open data?

_items.text: Data that is free of charge for anyone to use for any purpose
Data that anyone can access, use and share
Data that has the potential to become information

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Whereas all data has the potential to become information, open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. It might not always come free of charge, although it must be freely available.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Whereas all data has the potential to become information, open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. It might not always come free of charge, although it must be freely available.

displayTitle: How are HarvestAPI using open data?

_items.text: collate open data to make data art
teach others about open data internationally
publishes data to increase access to the Farmer register

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

HarvestAPI is an open source platform that publishes open agriculture data. This enables access to the Government of Jamaica Farmer register and enables developers to build products and services that are useful for the community.

_incorrect.final:
That's right!

HarvestAPI is an open source platform that publishes open agriculture data. This enables access to the Government of Jamaica Farmer register and enables developers to build products and services that are useful for the community.

body: Agriculture is a data-intensive sector. The access to, analysis and use of timely and accurate data about environmental conditions, production, market logistics and pricing, has become essential for the sector worldwide.
displayTitle: What is data, and why is it useful?
title: What is data, and why is it useful?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Data can be quantities, characters and symbols. It can come in the form of images, descriptions, reviews, prices or anything else that could form the basis of information. 

For example, the number of banana trees growing in farms across a parish, recorded in a spreadsheet, is data. The number of trees is the data, and the spreadsheet that holds the data is the dataset.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given a context.

For example, in comparing the number of banana trees to the geographical location of the farms, it might be deduced that banana production is greater in the eastern parishes than in the western parishes.

The collection and presentation of data helps to form information.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from information and personalized for your needs. Information turns to knowledge when you are able to make informed decisions or choices.

For example, drawing on information that banana production is greater in the eastern parishes region, the Producers group that manufactures snack foods from bananas might choose to focus their sourcing partnerships with farmers in the eastern parishes.

body: And as the world’s population grows from 7.4 billion to potentially 10 billion by 2050, the agricultural system will play a key role in ensuring our global demands can be met. Open data could be a key driver in improving the agricultural sector worldwide. In the Caribbean, there is huge potential to use open data to solve problems, improve processes and drive innovation within agriculture.
displayTitle: The benefits of open data for agriculture
title: The benefits of open data for agriculture
instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

_items.title: Increasing efficiency
_items.body:
Open data can improve the efficiency of logistics and make processes much more streamlined. 

Jamaica often suffers from coordination problems both in times of drought and of plenty. Open data platforms, which match demand and supply, can streamline crop production and planning. 

Access to consumption, production and crop maturity data can also enable policy-makers to make data-driven decisions on whether to increase or decrease local production and how much to export.

Enhanced access to geospatial and meteorological data helps farmers make better decisions about where and when to plant for the maximum yield, and how changes in weather patterns might affect crops. 

Using open data to drive mobile applications can also provide on-demand access to agricultural data from individuals and governments, supporting farmers working on the fields.

_items.title: Increasing transparency
_items.body:
Open data has the power to increase transparency in the agricultural sector.

Open access to procurement data can help ensure that procurement processes have been followed and best value tools and products have been invested in.

Open access to supply data can help to ensure that farmers get competitive prices for farming tools and products.

Open data can also help reduce decrease praedial larceny (theft of agricultural produce or livestock) in the Caribbean, which poses a huge threat to the sector.

Collecting and analysing open theft data will allow authorities to identify where in the production chain the thefts occur, and improve attempts to prevent them.

_items.title: Driving innovation
_items.body:
Publishing official open government agriculture data enables technical developers and domain experts to innovate and create products and services which boost the agriculture ecosystem.

Small startup ventures such as Agrocentral and HarvestAPI have started using agriculture price and production data produced by the Caribbean Ministry of Agriculture.

Other organisations, such as the Climate Corporation, have leveraged climate and soil open data to develop insurance products which help farmers protect and improve their farming operations, raising over $100m in venture capital.

_items.title: Enhancing collaboration
_items.body:
Studies currently estimate that only 30% of food purchased by Jamaican hotels is locally sourced. Opening supply and demand data improves collaboration between agriculture and key demand sectors such as tourism.

Crowdsourcing the collection of data can lead to increased availability and improved accuracy of open data. Encouraging farmers and other agricultural end-users to participate in the data collection or the verification process will increase data quality as well as quantity.

The government agency Rural Agricultural Development Authority (RADA), has collaborated with technology innovator Slashroots to create a platform for publishing and sharing of agricultural sector data across government and with the public.

body: Open data has the potential to...
displayTitle: Which TWO of the following are benefits of open data in agriculture?
title: Which TWO of the following are benefits of open data in agriculture?

_items.text: help make better decisions about where and when to plant crops
decrease soil salination (amount of salt in soil)
provide accurate and unbiased marketing information depicting current trade conditions.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Amongst other benefits, open data can help make better decisions and provide fair access to market. Open data can monitor the level of salt in soil but not necessary decrease it.

_incorrect.final:
That's right!

Amongst other benefits, open data can help make better decisions and provide fair access to market. Open data can monitor the level of salt in soil but not necessary decrease it.

body:
Agribusiness is the business of agricultural production.

Agribusiness consists of industry, commerce and trade. Industry includes the production of commodities and materials. Commerce and trade refer to the distribution of those commodities and materials.

In the Caribbean, agribusiness is essential, with agriculture contributing 15.6% to Dominica's GDP, 7.6% to St Vincent and the Grenadines' GDP and 7.4% to Jamaica's GDP in 2015 (source: World Bank). All these figures are lower than they were in 1995.
title: What is agribusiness?

body:
Agribusinesses boost the economy, contribute to domestic food supply and provide employment.

Taking the country of Jamaica: despite falling between 1995 and 2007, the contribution of agriculture to Jamaica’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP) has risen by 2.1% to 7.4% between 2007 and 2015.

Food exports from the island increased by 22.3%, moving from US$224 million in 2011 to US$274 million in 2012.

Jamaica agribusinesses produce a variety agricultural commodities for export. These include Tin Ackee, Callaloo, hot pepper sauce, Pickapeppa sauce, rum, beer, coffee products, Scotch Bonnet Pepper, Jerk BBQ Sauce, sugar, yam and sweet potato.

The sector currently employs 18% of the national workforce in Jamaica.
displayTitle: Why is agribusiness essential to the Caribbean?
title: Why is agribusiness essential to the Caribbean?

body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived. 

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. 

Using open data in agriculture will make processes more efficient and target decision making, which can improve crop yield, promote collaboration across the sector, and create new business and services.

However, open data is only valuable where it is being used. Some organisations and projects in the Caribbean are making huge steps towards improving agriculture with open data. To harness open data's full potential, and to get actors across the production chain sharing and using key datasets, the sector needs to adopt a culture that uses, produces and embraces data.

For more information on open data and agriculture, take a look at How can we improve agriculture, food and nutrition with open data? published by the Open Data Institute and GODAN.
title: Summary

body: How can data support the activities of agribusinesses?
title: Trends to watch in agriculture

_items.text: By providing evidence of product origin
By improving weather conditions
By increasing crop prices

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Agribusinesses are under increasing pressure to provide evidence of origin for their products and commodities. 

Sharing supply chain data between suppliers provides that evidence of origin. Publishing that data openly would provide that evidence to consumers.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Agribusinesses are under increasing pressure to provide evidence of origin for their products and commodities. 

Sharing supply chain data between suppliers provides that evidence of origin. Publishing that data openly would provide that evidence to consumers.

body:
Agriculture is a major industry in the Caribbean. However in recent years the industry has reduced in size and value, not just in the Caribbean but worldwide.

Agribusiness - the business of agriculture - is essential to reduce this declining trend. Agribusinesses boost the economy, contribute to domestic food supply and provide employment.

Agribusinesses can be split into three sectors: input, production and output. These three sectors cover all stages of the process, from 'pre-farm' to fork.

Given their size and importance in the Caribbean, agriculture and agribusinesses need to be constantly evolving. New technology, data, regulations and an ever increasing threat of food security both challenge and provide new opportunities to those working in the sector.
title: Summary

body: Agribusiness is a complex industry with many moving parts. There are three key sectors: input, production and output.
displayTitle: What are the sectors in agribusiness?
title: What are the sectors in agribusiness?
instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

_items.title: 1. Input
_items.body:
The input sector of agribusiness includes all resources involved in producing farm commodities.

Sometimes referred to as 'pre-farm', the input sector includes manufacturers of products such as plant seed, fertilisers, animal feed, machinery, fuel and chemicals.

Examples of input agribusinesses firms in Jamaica include Newport Fersan Chemicals, manufacturer and distributor of fertiliser and H&L AGRO (previously AgroGrace)

_items.title: 2. Production
_items.body:
Production is a key sector of agribusiness.

It includes groups such as farmers, fresh produce growers, companies producing seafood or growing trees and even ornamental plant producers.

The Jamaica Broilers Group is an example of one of the largest production agribusiness firms in the Caribbean.

_items.title: 3. Output
_items.body:
The output sector of agribusiness includes all services that link producers and consumers, from farm to fork.

This includes transportation, storage, packaging, inspections and sales, as well as the post-harvest processing of meat, fish and fruit and vegetables.

In Jamaica, the Marketing Extension Unit of the Rural Agricultural Development Agency (RADA) runs programs to assist farmers in the output sector.

The main roles of the unit are:

  • Assisting farmers with production planning for market sources
  • Assisting farmers with identifying and implementing appropriate marketing strategies for specific market sources
  • Training farmers and middlemen in post harvest handling of produce
  • Training farmers to operate in groups
  • Linking farmers with wholesalers, and retailers, supermarkets, green groceries, hotels and any other food-purchasing enterprises.

Which of the following best describes the output sector?
title: The sectors in agribusiness

_items.text: All services that link producers and consumers.
All 'pre-farm' resources involved in producing farm commodities
Groups such as farmers, fresh produce growers and companies that produce seafood

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The output sector of agribusiness includes all services that link producers and consumers.

This includes transportation, storage, packaging, inspections and sales, as well as the post-harvest processing of meat, fish and fruit and vegetables.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The output sector of agribusiness includes all services that link producers and consumers.

This includes transportation, storage, packaging, inspections and sales, as well as the post-harvest processing of meat, fish and fruit and vegetables.

body:
Agriculture is a major industry in the Caribbean. However in recent years the industry has reduced in size and value, not just in the Caribbean but worldwide.

Agribusiness - the business of agriculture - is essential to reduce this declining trend. Agribusinesses, encompassing all activities from 'pre-farm' to fork, boost the economy, contribute to domestic food supply and provide employment. 

In this module we will explore the following:

✓ What is agribusiness?

✓ What are the sectors in agribusiness?

✓ Why is agribusiness essential to the Caribbean?

✓ Trends to watch
title: Agribusiness

body: As such an important sector for the Caribbean and the world, agriculture needs to be constantly evolving. Below are five trends to watch as according to AgWeb.
title: Trends to watch
instruction: Click on the headings below to explore more

_items.title: New technology
_items.body:
From farm to fork, new technology is rapidly changing the way the agricultural sector works.

From drip irrigation to precision agriculture, 'smart farms' could save producers' money, increase the efficiency in operations and increase crop yields.

The International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) have built an interactive tool where you can see the effects of 11 new technologies on farms.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is playing an increasingly important role in many sectors, and agriculture is no exception.

From geospatial data, to food safety data; from land use data to market data, there are many valuable datasets to enrich the activities of agribusinesses.

Data can make agribusinesses more efficient, increase transparency of their operations (see regulations block below), drive innovation and enhance collaboration.

For more information about data and agriculture, take a look at this module.

_items.title: Biologicals
_items.body:
Across the sector, there is a shift from chemical to biological products in the fight against weeds, insects and diseases.

Controlling pests with biological products differs from chemical products and will require a different mindset.

A shift from chemical to biological products will also have an effect on companies who supply these products.

_items.title: Regulations
_items.body:
Agribusinesses are under increasing pressure to provide evidence of origin for their products and commodities. 

For some in the supply chain, this means an enormous overhaul of the way their operations are run.

Sharing supply chain data between suppliers is one way in which agribusinesses can be certain of the origin of their products and commodities. Publishing that data as open data would mean that consumers were equally certain.

_items.title: Food security
_items.body:
The world needs to produce at least 50% more food to feed 9 billion people by 2050. But climate change and changing landscapes could reduce crop yields by more than a quarter. 

Unless we change how we grow our food, food security—especially for the world’s poorest—will be at risk.

Many governments, NGOs and businesses are tackling the issue of food security, although they need the support of those on the ground - across input, production and output agribusinesses - to succeed.
